Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
On 8/16/21, youth was placed in lockdown in retaliation for telling on a staff member,
preventing youth from going on a field trip. Staff member calls youth inappropriate
names and speaks negatively about youth's weight. Staff member does not interject
when there are physical altercations between youth.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred for licensing investigation on 08/17/21. The complaint
noted the following:
Youth A has been placed at The Children Methodist Home since Mid-June of
2021. On 08/16/2021, Youth A was placed on lock down in retaliation from telling
on Staff 1 preventing Youth A from going to a waterpark. Staff 1 calls Youth A
"faggot, gay and speaks negatively about Youth A’s weight". Staff 1 does not get
involved with children in the facility, that are involved in physical
altercations…There are concerns that Staff 1 is neglecting the safety as Staff 1
stated " he can do what he wants, as nothing is going to happen to him. Other
complaints have been made by other children in the facility.
On 09/15/21, the complainant emailed to confirm that they had nothing else to add to
the original allegations.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 08/19/21. In regard to the allegations, Youth A
reported that Staff 1 and Staff 2 call youth, including Youth A, names such as, “fags,
gay, ladies, and fat.” Youth A reported that these names have been said by the staff
directly to him. Youth A said that other youths laugh when the staff say these things,
but Youth A takes offense and has told them to stop, but they haven’t. Youth A said
the last time this occurred with Staff 1 calling Youth A, Youth E, and Youth F “fags.”
Youth A reported that Staff 2, Staff 4, and maybe Staff 3 heard this. Youth A further
reported that Staff 1 has also made statements such as, “What is said in the cottage
stays in the cottage.” Youth A said that Staff 1 said this in response to Staff 1 being
mad about Youth A making a complaint about Staff 1 to Staff 5 and Staff 6. Youth A
said that he thinks he did not get to go on an outing because of making this
complaint. Youth A also said that Staff 1 has said that the youths cannot get him
fired or in trouble and that he hears what the youths say about him to others.
I interviewed Youths B, C, D, E, and F, on 08/19/21, at the facility. Youths B, C, and
D denied any name calling by staff. They also denied any intimidation, bullying, or
staff acting like they can treat youths poorly without consequences. Youths B and C
further denied that any staff allow youths to fight without breaking it up immediately.
Youth D reported that sometimes some staff (would not specify who) would take
their time intervening in fights. Youth D said this occurred months ago but is not
occurring currently. Youth E reported that one time, Staff 1 called him a thief when
Youth E stole something. Youth E said he has a history of stealing. Youth E said that
Staff 1 and Staff 2 do get loud sometimes, but don’t name call. Youth E denied that
4

staff allow youths to fight. None of the youth reported that the entire cottage would
be disciplined if one or two youth were getting in trouble.
Youth F reported that Staff 1 and Staff 2 call youth names such as the ones
identified in the allegations “all the time.” Youth F said the last time was the day
before when Staff 1 said for the group to “come and eat, fags” and “come and eat,
ladies.” Youth F said that Staff 2 heard this, as well as Staffs 3 and 4. Youth F said
that he reported something about this to Staff 5 last week and then Staff 1 started
talking about how the youths couldn’t get the staff fired. Youth F said that the group
has been punished for one to two youths acting out as well. These punishments
include early bedtimes and removal of electronics. Youth F said Staff 1 and Staff 2
also let youths fight. Youth F first said that this has not happened to Youth F directly,
but then said it last occurred two weeks ago when Youth F was in a fight with a peer
and Staff 2 sat there and laughed before breaking it up. Youth F said that other
youths and staff were around but did not recall specifically who.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 08/19/21. Staff 1 denied calling the youths
names as noted in the allegations. Staff 1 said that the youths “twist” things, such as
when he has spoken to some youths about overeating or snacking too much, they
later said he called them fat. Staff 1 said that Youth A is one of the youths who has
this tendency to take things the wrong way. Regarding using the terms “fag” or “gay,”
Staff 1 denied calling youths those names. Staff 1 reported that Youth F told the
group that he was gay by saying, “I’m gay. I’m a fag.” Youth F mentioned to the
group that he has acted out with Youth E as well. Staff 1 said that he addressed
Youth F on using the word “fag,” but it was at that point that other youths started
calling him names. The staff address the youth when they use those words. Staff 1
denied calling youths “retarded, ladies, idiots,” or other names. Staff 1 also denied
saying or suggesting that he can’t get fired, but noted that he has addressed the
youths’ comments of intending to get staff fired in group settings. Staff 1 said he told
the youths that he doesn’t do anything to get fired and that they can make whatever
complaints they want to. Staff 1 denied using consequences for the whole cottage
for one to two youths’ misbehavior. Staff 1 did state that the whole group sometimes
acts out and that’s when they would all receive consequences like early bedtimes or
removing Netflix privileges. Staff 1 said that he and the other staff always intervene
in fights and to so immediately. Staff 1 said that they step between youths and
separate them. He denied allowing youth to fight or laughing while youths were
fighting. Staff 1 denied not allowing Youth A on the outing for voicing his concerns.
I interviewed Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 at the facility on 08/19/21. All of these staff
confirmed that they typically work in this cottage, and all have worked with Staff 1.
None of the staff reported hearing Staff 1, Staff 2, or any other staff call the youth
names. Staff 2 said that youth sometimes take things the wrong way, but denied
calling youth names, such as in the allegations. Staff 2 reported that Youth F has
told the other residents that he had a boyfriend, and the other boys were calling him
“gay,” but not staff. Staff 3 said that there was one time that staff told Youth E to stop
being a thief after Youth E had stolen something. Youth E has reportedly stolen
5

numerous times. Staff 3 said that the staff don’t call the youth names, but the youths
use those names with one another and toward staff. Staff 3 identified Youth F as one
youth who name calls and makes sexual comments. Staffs 2, 3, and 4 denied any
knowledge of any staff saying things like they could do what they wanted to the
youth and not get in trouble or fired. All three denied saying or suggesting that
themselves as well. All three staff denied that any staff let youths fight or sit and
laugh when youth fight. Staff 2 said that the youth will sometimes say that staff let
them fight, if the youth was hit in the process and feels that he needs to blame it on
the staff. Staff 2 denied letting youth fight or laughing at youth while they were
fighting. Staff 3 did identify Staff 7 as being “lazy” and slow to respond to anything.
Staff 3 said that Staff 7 does not let youths fight, but does not observe the youth’s
behaviors well, so there may be more fights when Staff 7 is there. The staff also
reported that some of the youths have made remarks about trying to get staff fired.
During telephone calls and emails with Youth A’s worker, the worker established a
safety plan to have Youth A separated from Staff 1 during this investigation. I
advised Youth A’s worker that Youth A identified his therapist, family worker, and
Staff 3 as individuals he could go to with concerns.
I asked Administrator 2 if staff were allowed to change the daily schedule that was
provided for my review. On 08/24/21, Administrator 2 emailed,
Our goal is to have a consistent schedule. However, in residential the staff can
adjust the schedule based upon what is going on in the cottage. For example, if
they are having major problems with youth being aggressive etc., they could ask
that they spend time in their rooms to help settle the cottage.
On 09/15/21, I emailed Staff 5 to inquire about the allegations noted in this report.
Staff 5 replied with the following,
When I have talked with Youth A in the past during events or in passing, he has
informed me that Staff 1 has bullied him, called him names, and has told him and
others in the cottage “what is said in the cottage stays in the cottage.” He has
also said to me that it is a “Loyalty” environment in his cottage where if the youth
doesn’t say anything then they have more privileges such as TV, electronics, and
time outside. As soon as I was told this information I informed my supervisor,
who also brought in the Chief Administrator for me to inform as well.
Staff 5 reported further that she advised the Chief Administrator on 08/13/21.
On 09/15/21, I emailed Staff 6 to inquire about the allegations noted in this report.
Staff 6 replied with the following,
Thank you for reaching out. Youth A mentioned to me that Staff 1 has called him
and the youth “snitches” if he or they “told on” others for something. He also had
stated that Staff 1 would not allow him and a peer to talk to or be around a
certain MCHS employee (Staff 5). When asked, Youth A said that it was because
of something that he and the peer said to her that “could get Staff 1 in trouble,
and he [Staff 1] had a meeting with admin.” He did not want to tell me specific
details about the situation or conversation when asked. After this, he said that he
6

felt targeted by Staff 1 in that he was not allowed to go off-grounds for an activity
but the other peer that also talked to Staff 5 was allowed to go.
On 09/15/21, the Chief Administrator emailed the following,
On Monday August 16th, a member of the development team notified her
supervisor that a Harrison Cottage youth informed her that the youth are not
allowed to leave the cottage or attend outings/events. There was an off-site water
park event on the 16th which was facilitated by Development. Administrator 2
was notified who immediately began an internal review and on the
16th interviewed Staff 1, cottage supervisor X and Shift Supervisor.
During emails and telephone call on 09/21/21, Administrator 2 reported that she was
told from the Chief Administrator, who had heard the report from someone else, of
some concerns mostly related to the youth not being able to attend some outings.
Administrator 2 said that she began an internal review but stopped when this
investigation began as she assumed it was one in the same and did not want to
interfere in the investigation. Per Administrator 2, the complaint she received was
general and not specific to cottages, staff, or youth. Administrator 2 said that she did
speak to Staff 1, as well as other staff, about this and let him and the others know
that the youth should be attending activities and outings unless there was some
extreme behavioral or other issue preventing safe participation. Administrator 2 said
that there had been a recent water park activity put on by the facility’s Development
program and reminded the staff that the youths should be attending events like this.
Administrator 2 also reported that she spoke to Staff 1 about one boy reporting that
he was called “fat.” Staff 1 denied calling any youth “fat” and said that he talked to
them about health and eating habits.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation is as follows with applicable
information outlined:
 Staff 1 has no disciplinary action in his employee record
 Daily schedule for Harrison Cottage with sleeping hours noted
 Facility policy Section E. Number 11. Behavior Intervention Plan.
 Facility policy Section F. Number 6. Child Discipline Policy. MCHS does not
sanction any form of verbal, nonverbal, or emotional abuse such as but not
limited to; swearing, screaming at children, yelling at children, ridiculing,
sarcasm toward youth, unflattering nicknames, withholding of food,
humiliation, derogatory comments about children and/or the children’s
families, cursing, or any other non-sanctioned approaches, etc.
 Facility policy Section F. Number 16. Consequences. …Various
consequences can include not allowing a child to participate in an
activity…Other rules to remember when it comes to implementing
consequences: 1. The final decision on consequences rests with the cottage
supervisor. He/she must solicit feedback from the staff, case managers,
therapists, and management.
 Facility policy Section F. Number 18. Physical Intervention.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(b) Disciplining a group for the misbehavior of individual
group members.
(c) Verbal abuse, ridicule, or humiliation.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule. There is insufficient
evidence to support the allegations that staff are calling youth
names, bullying youth, or using group consequences for
individual behavior. Although two of the youth interviewed did
report this, the other four did not. None of the staff reported
hearing or using name calling with youth. None of the staff
reported use of group consequences for select youth
misbehavior. The use of removal of privileges, such as not
allowing a youth on an outing, is provided for within the facility’s
“consequences” policy.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is highly recommended that thorough documentation of
implementation of consequences occurs in order to provide a
clear understanding of what consequences were used with
youth, and why they were implemented. Documentation of the
required supervisor, clinical team and management review
should also be documented, as it is required in the facility policy
for implementation of consequences.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
8

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Youth are not allowed to leave their rooms until 10:30 AM and are sent to their
rooms around 6:30 PM.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred for licensing investigation on 08/17/21. The complaint
noted the following:
The children awake by 8:00am but are not allowed to leave their room until
10:30am. The children are being sent to their rooms around 6:30pm instead of
8:30pm.
I interviewed six youth for this investigation (Youths A, B, C, D, E, and F). All of them
reported that summer and weekend bedtimes are between 8:00-9:30pm. Two youth
reported that during school they went to bed between 7:00-8:00pm. Five of the youth
reported that they wake up at 10:30am. The youth consistently reported that if they
wake up prior to 10:30am, they are not allowed to come out of their rooms other than
to use the restroom, get something to drink, and get some fruit if they are hungry. If
they come out of their rooms, they must return and remain until 10:30am.
I interviewed four staff for this investigation (Staffs 1, 2, 3, and 4). Staff 1 reported
that when the youth wake up, they do their hygiene, clean rooms, and do their
chores, and they are done with all of that by 10:30am. Staff 1 reported that if the
youth wake up and are done with all of that before 10:30am, that they are allowed to
come out of their rooms. All four staff reported that bedtimes during the summer and
weekends are between 8:00-9:00pm. Staffs 2, 3, and 4 said bedtime hours during
school was between 7:00-8:00pm, while Staff 1 said it was between 8:00-9:00pm.
Staffs 2, 3, and 4 said that the youth are to remain in their rooms but can do hygiene
and clean their room until 10:30am. Staff 3 said that having the youth remain in
rooms until 10:30am was a “Methodist thing.” Early bedtime was consistently
reported by the staff as 6:30pm and would be implemented for misbehavior such as
fighting or property damage. This was noted to be specific to the youth involved and
not for the whole cottage unless the whole cottage was involved.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation is as follows with applicable
information outlined:
• Daily schedule for Harrison Cottage with sleeping hours noted. Weekend hours
specify wake up at 8:00am with option to sleep in until 10:30am. School day
wake up times were listed as 6:30-7:00am. Bedtime was noted between 9:00-
9:30pm for all days of the week.
9

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is noncompliant with the rule as they have an
established daily schedule that outlines bedtime hours, but the
staff are not following that schedule. It was established by youth
and staff reports, that the youth typically go to bed around 7:00-
8:00pm on school days and 8:00-9:30pm on summer days and
weekends. The youth, and three of four staff, reported that if
they don’t have school that the youths are expected to remain in
their rooms until 10:30am. They are permitted to come out to
use the restroom, get something to drink, or get some fruit if
hungry, but are expected to go back to their rooms and remain
there until 10:30am. If the group or individual youth have
demonstrated behavioral issues, they might have received an
“early bedtime” which is reportedly around 6:30pm. These times
are extending well beyond the established bedtime hours and
result in youths being in their rooms for periods of up to 16
hours at a time. This is well beyond a reasonable time for
sleeping hours, which should not be longer than 10 hours in
rooms. The facility is permitted to allow youth to sleep in beyond
the established sleeping hours but is not permitted to require
youth to remain in their rooms beyond the established sleeping
hours for these extended periods. To do so is bordering on
seclusion of the youth, so the facility must clarify the sleeping
hours and advise the staff of the clarification as part of their
corrective action plan.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting a timely
and acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.
